content.body: the `#set` creates a private setter
content.formatted_body: the #set creates a private setter

the #set creates a private setter

content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> wait, this creates a _visible_ private field whose name is derived from the name of the accessor? i thought decorator's auto-accessors created private fields which you couldn't actually refer to (even in the body of the class)

No. It's not visible, has a private field that you cannot access directly (must use the #set)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to bakkot
wait, this creates a visible private field whose name is derived from the name of the accessor? i thought decorator's auto-accessors created private fields which you couldn't actually refer to (even in the body of the class)
No. It's not visible, has a private field that you cannot access directly (must use the #set)

content.body: I think it's like if you do `accessor x { get; #set }` then you have a paired getter `this.x` and setter `this.#x`

content.body: bakkot, ljharb: I'm fine with stage 2 for duplicate named capture groups. The remaining discussion issue is the property creation order issue. I'd prefer the order to be fixed for a given regexp, not variable from invocation to invocation. Looks like some of you agree?

content.body: littledan: basically as previously written, `Object.keys(/(?<a>.)(?<b>.)|(?<b>.)(?<a>.)/.exec(foo).groups)` would be either \['a', 'b'\] or \['b', 'a'\] depending on which alternative actually took part in the match
content.formatted_body: littledan: basically as previously written, Object.keys(/(?<a>.)(?<b>.)|(?<b>.)(?<a>.)/.exec(foo).groups) would be either ['a', 'b'] or ['b', 'a'] depending on which alternative actually took part in the match

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: littledan: basically as previously written, `Object.keys(/(?<a>.)(?<b>.)|(?<b>.)(?<a>.)/.exec(foo).groups)` would be either \['a', 'b'\] or \['b', 'a'\] depending on which alternative actually took part in the match

littledan: basically as previously written, Object.keys(/(?<a>.)(?<b>.)|(?<b>.)(?<a>.)/.exec(foo).groups) would be either ['a', 'b'] or ['b', 'a'] depending on which alternative actually took part in the match

content.body: now it's unconditionally the order in which the group names first appeared in the regex (here, ['a', 'b'])

content.body:
the solution on slide 18 seems to make sense, in which observable behavior (specifically, objects are valid input while strings are not) is strictly weaker than Temporal

and the spec text supporting that can be written with Temporal compatibility in mind but without an actual dependency upon new observable behavior introduced by Temporal

content.body:
> <@littledan:matrix.org> it can be good to coordinate expectations about this subset, but I don't think this requires making a new repo, seeking consensus on advancement, etc

btw I also don't think you need my/committee consensus to do this refactoring of the AOs from one place to the other, or for moving the semantics at the intersection of the proposals from one side to the other. Feel free to go ahead as far as I'm concerned/as far as I understand TC39 process.
